metadata.titleEn: Daily 0.25 fused snow water equivalent product in China (1980–2020)
metadata.description: Snow water equivalent (SWE) is one of the important parameters to characterize the water resources of snow cover and sensitive to global climate change. A spatiotemporal gradient boosting model (XGBoost) was developed, combining five SWE products (GlobSnow, ERA5-Land, ERA-Interim, GLDAS, and 1980–2020 China daily snow water equivalent product dataset) and spatiotemporal covariates (land cover, temperature, snow-related, geospatial, and temporal features). This model considers the spatiotemporal heterogeneity of SWE and the nonlinear relationship between SWE and multiple influencing factors. Evaluations results on daily SWE records from 647 meteorological sites in China demonstrates the effectiveness of the model with R values of 0.77,0.70, and MAE and RMSE values of 7.54, 8.62 mm and 12.29, 13.73mm. Based on this model, daily snow water equivalent product with a resolution of 0.25 degrees in China was produced from 1980 to 2020. This dataset provides more accurate snow water equivalent data for snow water management.
metadata.instructions:
File name: Daily snow water equivalent product in China (1980-2020) is stored in tif format. The file name is "XGB_SWE_DAILY_025_yyyymmdd.tif", where YYYY represents the year, mm represents the month, and dd represents the date. Taking “XGB_SWE_DAILT_025_19800101.tif” as an example, this tif file describes the snow water equivalent in China on January 1, 1980.
Data read: All tif files in the dataset can be opened directly with Arcgis.
Note: Due to the use of existing snow water equivalent products to mask the product, the product was not completely continuous from 1980 to 2020, and the missing data date is detailed in the missing_data_time.txt document

background: Accurate snow water equivalent (SWE) data are crucial for estimating the water supply capacity of snow and are of profound importance for the communities of hydrology, climatology, and ecology. Snow occupies over 50% of the land area in the Northern Hemisphere during the winter and is a crucial element of the cryosphere and global energy cycle due to its high albedo and low thermal conductivity. Snowmelt runoff provides a stable and reliable water supply for terrestrial rivers in mid- and high-latitude areas, and more than one-sixth of the world population depends upon glaciers and seasonal snowpacks for water. Snow Water Equivalent (SWE) is a measure of the water content in a snowpack and represents the amount of water available for runoff. Therefore, it has significant impacts on hydrological processes, climate, and ecosystems. SWE estimation methods include spatial interpolation estimation based on ground-measured sites, data assimilation, passive microwave remote sensing inversion, active microwave remote sensing inversion, reconstruction, physical models, and lidar measurement technology. Among the various methods, passive microwave remote sensing inversion, data assimilation, and reconstruction methods are widely used to produce vast-area and long-term SWE products, namely, satellite-based SWE, data assimilation SWE, and reanalysis SWE, respectively. Satellite-based SWE products observe brightness temperature as a function of snowpack properties and possess advantages in identifying the spatial pattern and temporal variation of SWE. Data assimilation SWE products are generally derived from Land Data Assimilation Systems by using ground-based observations, remote sensing products, and/or reanalysis forcing. Compared to data assimilation SWE, reanalysis SWE products provide relatively more continuous and integral records based on a numerical weather prediction model, which assimilates earth observations over a long historical period into the weather prediction model. However, in addition to the above-mentioned advantages, different SWE products have disadvantages in terms of uncertainty and incompleteness. The uncertainty of satellite-based products is mainly attributed to topographic and climatic factors, and that of reanalysis and data assimilation products is partly attributed to several structural errors and inputs of in situ data, such as altitude bias caused by spatial differences between grids and sites. Regarding data incompleteness, due to the limited detection capability of passive microwaves in mountainous regions, GlobSnow SWE only provides terrestrial non-mountainous regions of the Northern Hemisphere between latitudes 35°–85°N, excluding glaciers and Greenland. Moreover, existing SWE products are inconsistent with each other and show diverse spatiotemporal patterns. A comparison of five SWE gridded products throughout the Northern Hemisphere was conducted, showing that the consistency of five products is only approximately 50% in the climatological peak snow mass. As a result, these datasets exhibited exceedingly distinct SWE trends.
research objective: This study proposes a novel spatiotemporal fusion model to estimate SWE by combining multisource SWE products (GlobSnow, ERA-Interim, ERA5-Land, GLDAS, and CSWE) and spatiotemporal covariates (land cover, temperature, snow-related, geospatial, and temporal features) with the extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost) model. Using the proposed model, a dataset of daily SWE from 1980 to 2020 with a spatial resolution of 25 km over China is provided, aiming to deliver accurate SWE data for hydrological research and water resource management.
challenges: First, the performance of the XGBoost model is partly dependent on the abundance of observation samples. The insufficient number and relatively uneven distribution of samples would result in uncertainty for the model, e.g., the model accuracy in May (samples of 76) and that in QTP (samples of 355) are inferior to other periods and regions, respectively. Second, the QTP has the most complex terrain conditions among the three stable snow cover areas in China, which poses a great challenge to SWE estimation. In addition, the performances of the member products vary in QTP: ERA5-Land and GLDAS show plentiful abnormally high values (> 200 mm), while ERA-Interim and CSWE show very low values (< 30 mm). Third, the uncertainty from scaling differences should not be ignored. The limited representation of in situ SWE sites makes it challenging to evaluate SWE estimates at the gridded scale.
methods: Based on the XGBoost model, we add spatiotemporal features explaining the heterogeneity of SWE to construct a spatiotemporal XGBoost model. We use the K-fold cross-validation strategy to train and validate the model, which is suitable for small samples through its advantage of repeatedly using randomly generated subsamples for training and validation at the same time. Specifically, we conduct SWE accuracy evaluations using ground measurement data from 2013 to 2017 based on the annual and site cross-validation strategy to validate the spatiotemporal prediction of the model.
dataset: Evaluation results on daily SWE records from 647 meteorological sites in China show that the proposed XGBoost SWE outperforms existing SWE products and other fusion methods.
findings: The comparison of the accuracies of XGBoost SWE and member products shows that the XGBoost SWE based on both annual and site cross-validation achieves apparently higher accuracy with improved regression lines, demonstrating the prediction ability of the spatiotemporal XGBoost model. Compared with the member products, the accuracy of the XGBoost SWE decreases the MAE and RMSE from 12.90 to 18.21 mm to 7.54, 8.62 mm and from 19.02 to 25.27 mm to 12.29, 13.73 mm, respectively, and increases the R from 0.36 to 0.51 to 0.77, 0.70, respectively. XGBoost SWE surpasses all products with MAEs of 5.68 – 7.39 mm, RMSEs of 7.68 – 11.50 mm, and R of 0.49 – 0.85 at elevations lower than 2000 m, showing an apparent improvement in estimation due to the abundant samples.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'data assimilation' in the context of SWE products?
Definition.Answer: In the context of SWE products, 'data assimilation' refers to a method that integrates ground-based observations, remote sensing products, and/or reanalysis forcing data within Land Data Assimilation Systems to produce SWE products. This approach aims to create more continuous and comprehensive SWE records by incorporating diverse datasets into a cohesive framework, enhancing the spatial and temporal resolution of SWE estimations.

Definition.Question: What does 'K-fold cross-validation strategy' mean in the context of evaluating SWE estimation models?
Definition.Answer: In the context of evaluating SWE estimation models, the 'K-fold cross-validation strategy' is a method used to train and validate models, especially when dealing with small sample sizes. This strategy involves dividing the dataset into K subsets, or folds, and using a combination of these folds for training while the remaining fold is used for validation. It allows for repeated use of randomly generated subsamples for both training and validation, providing a robust assessment of the model's predictive performance and generalizability.

Comparison.Question: How does the accuracy of snow water equivalent (SWE) estimation using the XGBoost model compare to traditional data assimilation methods in terms of MAE and RMSE?
Comparison.Answer: The XGBoost SWE estimation shows improved accuracy compared to existing SWE products and other fusion methods. It decreases the MAE and RMSE from 12.90 to 18.21 mm to 7.54, 8.62 mm and from 19.02 to 25.27 mm to 12.29, 13.73 mm, respectively.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the spatiotemporal features used in the XGBoost model contribute differently to SWE estimation compared to traditional spatial interpolation methods?
Comparison.Answer: The spatiotemporal features in the XGBoost model help explain the heterogeneity of SWE, allowing the model to utilize both temporal and spatial covariates such as land cover, temperature, and snow-related features, which may not be fully captured by traditional spatial interpolation methods.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data completeness and uncertainty between satellite-based SWE products and the XGBoost model-generated SWE dataset?
Comparison.Answer: Satellite-based SWE products face challenges with data completeness, especially in mountainous regions, and have uncertainties due to topographic and climatic factors. The XGBoost model, by fusing multiple SWE products and incorporating spatiotemporal covariates, aims to reduce these uncertainties and improve data completeness.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise from the scaling differences between in situ SWE measurements and gridded datasets, and how can data collection methods be adapted to improve the evaluation of SWE estimates at different scales?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges from scaling differences include limited representativeness of in situ measurements and potential biases when comparing different spatial resolutions. To improve evaluation, data collection methods might involve increasing the density and distribution of in situ sites, integrating remote sensing data with ground observations, and developing algorithms that account for spatial discrepancies. These adaptations could enhance the accuracy and applicability of SWE estimates across various scales.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the challenges in estimating snow water equivalent (SWE) on the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The Tibetan Plateau presents complex terrain conditions that pose significant challenges for SWE estimation. Additionally, the performance of various SWE products on the Plateau varies significantly, with some products showing abnormally high or low values. This variability introduces uncertainty in SWE estimation.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the uncertainty in satellite-based snow water equivalent (SWE) products?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Uncertainty in satellite-based SWE products is primarily attributed to topographic and climatic factors. These factors can affect the accuracy of satellite observations and lead to variations in SWE estimates across different regions and conditions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the likely outcomes on the accuracy of snow water equivalent data when utilizing a spatiotemporal fusion model that integrates multiple SWE products and spatiotemporal covariates?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating multiple SWE products and spatiotemporal covariates using a spatiotemporal fusion model like XGBoost can improve the accuracy of snow water equivalent data by leveraging the strengths and mitigating the weaknesses of individual SWE products, leading to decreased mean absolute error (MAE) and root mean square error (RMSE), and increased correlation coefficient (R) in predictions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects on the estimation of snow water equivalent data when the number and distribution of observation samples are inadequate?
Causal Consequence.Answer: An inadequate number and uneven distribution of observation samples may lead to increased uncertainty and reduced accuracy in snow water equivalent estimations, as it affects the model's performance, especially in complex terrains like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, where model accuracy can be inferior due to insufficient sample representation.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of integrating multiple SWE products and spatiotemporal covariates using a model like XGBoost for SWE estimation?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to deliver accurate SWE data for hydrological research and water resource management by combining multisource SWE products and spatiotemporal covariates with the XGBoost model, resulting in a dataset of daily SWE from 1980 to 2020 with a spatial resolution of 25 km over China.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to consider the heterogeneity of SWE and the non-linear relationships with influencing factors in SWE estimation?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important because considering the heterogeneity of SWE and its non-linear relationships with influencing factors allows for a high-precision estimation of snow water equivalent, which is crucial for understanding the spatial and temporal variation of SWE and improving the accuracy of water resource management.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intentions behind using ground measurement data for accuracy evaluations of SWE products?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intention is to validate the spatiotemporal prediction of the model by conducting SWE accuracy evaluations using ground measurement data, ensuring that the proposed XGBoost SWE outperforms existing SWE products and other fusion methods, leading to more reliable data for scientific and practical applications.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in integrating multiple SWE products with spatiotemporal covariates to improve snow water equivalent estimation accuracy?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The process involves constructing a spatiotemporal XGBoost model by integrating multiple SWE products (such as GlobSnow, ERA5-Land, ERA-Interim, GLDAS, and CSWE) with spatiotemporal covariates like land cover, temperature, snow-related features, geospatial and temporal data. This integration considers the nonlinear relationship between SWE and various influencing factors, enhancing the estimation accuracy over a large area and long-term timeframe.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is K-fold cross-validation utilized to train and validate models when dealing with small sample sizes in SWE estimation?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: K-fold cross-validation is used by dividing the dataset into K subsets and using each subset as a validation set while the remaining subsets are used for training. This method allows for repeated random subsampling, which is suitable for small samples, ensuring that each sample is used for both training and validation across different iterations. This approach is applied to evaluate the accuracy of SWE predictions using ground measurement data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What challenges are encountered in estimating SWE over complex terrains like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, and how can these be addressed procedurally?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Challenges in estimating SWE over complex terrains like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau include the uneven distribution of observation samples and varying terrain conditions that affect model accuracy. Procedurally, these challenges can be addressed by enhancing model input with more abundant and diverse samples, adjusting model parameters to account for terrain complexity, and using a combination of different SWE products to balance their respective strengths and limitations.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the integration of multiple SWE products for enhanced snow water equivalent estimation?
Enablement.Answer: The use of data fusion models like XGBoost allows for the integration of multiple SWE products, combining sources such as GlobSnow, ERA-Interim, ERA5-Land, GLDAS, and CSWE, along with spatiotemporal covariates like land cover and temperature, enhancing the estimation of snow water equivalent.

Enablement.Question: How does incorporating spatiotemporal features enable more accurate snow water equivalent estimation in complex terrains?
Enablement.Answer: Incorporating spatiotemporal features such as geospatial and temporal data helps explain the heterogeneity of snow water equivalent, especially in complex terrains like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, thus improving the accuracy of SWE estimation using models like XGBoost.

Enablement.Question: What challenges must be addressed to enable effective evaluation of SWE estimates at the gridded scale?
Enablement.Answer: To effectively evaluate SWE estimates at the gridded scale, challenges such as the limited representation of in situ SWE sites and the scaling differences that contribute to estimation uncertainty must be addressed.

Expectation.Question: Why might the XGBoost model's performance be variable across different regions and time periods when estimating snow water equivalent (SWE)?
Expectation.Answer: The performance of the XGBoost model is partly dependent on the abundance of observation samples. An insufficient number and relatively uneven distribution of samples can result in uncertainty for the model. For example, the model accuracy in May and in the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau (QTP) is inferior to other periods and regions due to the scarcity of samples and complex terrain conditions, respectively.

Expectation.Question: Why does the combination of multiple SWE products and spatiotemporal covariates potentially enhance the accuracy of SWE estimation?
Expectation.Answer: Combining multiple SWE products (GlobSnow, ERA-Interim, ERA5-Land, GLDAS, and CSWE) with spatiotemporal covariates (land cover, temperature, snow-related, geospatial, and temporal features) using a spatiotemporal XGBoost model helps in addressing the spatial and temporal heterogeneity of SWE. This approach leverages the strengths of different datasets and covariates to improve estimation accuracy by considering nonlinear relationships between SWE and its influencing factors.

Expectation.Question: Why do existing SWE products exhibit significant inconsistencies and diverse spatiotemporal patterns in their datasets?
Expectation.Answer: Existing SWE products show inconsistencies due to factors like topographic and climatic influences on satellite-based products, structural errors in data assimilation and reanalysis products, and limited detection capabilities in mountainous regions. These factors contribute to diverse spatiotemporal patterns and inconsistencies in SWE datasets, as demonstrated by a comparison of five SWE gridded products, which revealed only approximately 50% consistency in the climatological peak snow mass.

Judgmental.Question: How might the challenges of topographic complexity and sample distribution in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau affect the reliability of snow water equivalent data collection?
Judgmental.Answer: The topographic complexity and uneven sample distribution in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau present challenges for SWE estimation, introducing uncertainty into the model's performance. These factors can lead to variability in SWE estimates, as seen with discrepancies in SWE values among different products in this region. This affects the reliability of data collection by complicating the representation of in situ SWE sites at a gridded scale.

Judgmental.Question: What is the assessment of the potential of passive microwave remote sensing inversion as a method for large-scale and long-term SWE data collection?
Judgmental.Answer: Passive microwave remote sensing inversion is regarded as a valuable method for large-scale and long-term SWE data collection due to its ability to observe brightness temperature as a function of snowpack properties. It is advantageous in identifying spatial patterns and temporal variations of SWE. However, its effectiveness can be limited by topographic and climatic factors, leading to uncertainty and data incompleteness, especially in mountainous regions.

Assertion.Question: I can't figure out how the gradient boosting model can effectively handle the spatial and temporal heterogeneity in estimating snow water equivalent.
Assertion.Answer: The gradient boosting model, specifically XGBoost, incorporates spatiotemporal features such as land cover, temperature, snow-related characteristics, and geospatial and temporal features. This approach helps in addressing the heterogeneity by capturing the nonlinear relationships between SWE and these covariates.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced when using different SWE products to create a fused dataset.
Assertion.Answer: The challenges include the uncertainty and incompleteness of the individual SWE products, which can be influenced by topographic and climatic factors, structural errors, and the limited detection capability of certain methods like passive microwaves in mountainous regions. Additionally, scaling differences and inconsistent spatiotemporal patterns in existing products pose significant challenges.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand why evaluating the SWE estimates at the gridded scale is difficult with the available in situ data.
Assertion.Answer: Evaluating SWE estimates at the gridded scale is challenging because of the limited representation of in situ SWE sites. The disparity between grid-scale estimates and site-specific measurements can lead to difficulties in accurately assessing the performance of SWE estimates.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and analyze the effectiveness of different fusion models in integrating multisource SWE products with spatiotemporal covariates.
Request/Directive.Answer: The effectiveness of fusion models like the spatiotemporal XGBoost model is demonstrated by their ability to integrate multisource SWE products and spatiotemporal covariates, offering improved SWE estimation. The spatiotemporal XGBoost model, which incorporates features such as land cover and temperature, outperformed existing SWE products by achieving higher accuracy in regression metrics, such as reducing MAE and RMSE and increasing correlation coefficient R. These results suggest that fusion models can effectively address the limitations of individual SWE products by leveraging their combined strengths.

Request/Directive.Question: Please suggest strategies for validating the accuracy of SWE datasets using ground measurement data, considering the limitations of existing validation methods.
Request/Directive.Answer: Validation of SWE datasets using ground measurement data can be enhanced by employing strategies such as the K-fold cross-validation technique, which allows for effective training and validation with limited samples. The use of annual and site cross-validation strategies can also help in assessing the spatiotemporal prediction capabilities of SWE models. However, to address the limited representation of in situ SWE sites, expanding the network of ground measurement stations and incorporating more diverse environmental conditions in the validation process are crucial steps for improving dataset accuracy.
